awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC: Collaborative Research: Two-Phase Dynamics of Temperate Ice
awd_abstract_narration:
Iverson/1643120

This award supports a project to study temperate ice, using both experimental methods and modeling, in order to determine the effect of water on its flow resistance and structure and to study the mobility of water within the ice.  A new mathematical model of ice stream flow and temperature is developed in conjunction with these experiments. The model includes water production, storage, and movement in deforming ice and their effects on flow resistance at ice stream margins and on water availability for lubrication of ice stream beds.  Results will improve estimates of the evolution of ice stream speed and geometry in a warming climate, and so improve the accuracy of assessments of the contribution of the Antarctic ice sheet to sea level rise over the next century.  Ice streams are zones of rapid flow within the Antarctic ice sheet and are primarily responsible for its discharge of ice to the ocean and major effect on sea-level rise. Water plays a central role in the flow of ice streams. It lubricates their bases and softens their margins, where flow speeds abruptly transition from rapid to slow. Within ice stream margins some ice is "temperate", meaning that it is at its melting temperature and thus contains intercrystalline water that significantly softens the ice. Two postdoctoral researchers will be supported, trained, and mentored for academic careers, and three undergraduates will be introduced to research in the geosciences.

This award is part the NSF/GEO-UK NERC lead agency opportunity (NSF 14-118) and is a collaboration between Iowa State University in the United States and Oxford University in the United Kingdom.  The two-phase deformation of temperate ice will be studied, with the objective of determining its effect on the flow of Antarctic ice streams.  The project has two components that reinforce each other. First there will be laboratory experiments in which a rotary device at Iowa State University will be used to determine relationships between the water content of temperate ice and its rheology and permeability. The second component will involve the development at Oxford University of a two-phase, fluid-dynamical theory of temperate ice and application of this theory in models of ice-stream dynamics. Results of the experiments will guide the constitutive rules and parameter ranges considered in the theory, and application of elements of the theory will improve interpretations of the experimental results.  The theory and resultant models will predict the coupled distributions of temperate ice, water, stress, deformation, and basal slip that control the evolution of ice-stream speed and geometry. The modeling will result in parameterizations that allow ice streaming to be included in continental-scale models of ice sheets in a simplified but physically defensible way.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The speeds of the fastest moving parts of ice sheets and of most smaller glaciers are controlled, in part, by the deformation of ice that is at its melting temperature (so-called warm ice). Such ice contains a small fraction of liquid water that resides mostly at the edges of individual ice crystals. This water is thought to reduce the viscosity of ice and thus make it flow more easily, affecting the amount of ice conveyed to the oceans by ice sheets and the associated rate of sea-level rise.

We reconfigured a custom laboratory device to study in experiments the deformation of warm ice that contains liquid water (Fig. 1) and built and began using a new laboratory device called a permeameter to measure the permeability of this ice (Fig. 2). Permeability describes the ease at which water flows through ice and helps control its liquid water content.  We learned the following:

1) Ice with sufficient liquid water (>0.6%) deforms at a rate that is linearly proportional to the stress on ice (Fig. 3), across most of the range of stresses expected in glaciers.  Only at unusually high stresses (>0.16 MPa) does this watery ice deform at a rate that depends on approximately the cube of the stress (Fig. 3), which is the traditional relationship used in computer models to predict ice flow rates regardless of the stress magnitude.  The warm, watery ice that characterizes fast moving glaciers, therefore, behaves markedly differently than is usually assumed in computer models of fast glacier flow. This different behavior likely is the result of melting and refreezing at crystal boundaries that is expected to be especially efficient if ice is both warm and watery.

2)  The permeability of such ice, which had not been measured prior to this study, depends on roughly the square of the water content (Fig. 4). It also depends on the sizes of ice crystals and the connectivity of water-filled veins at the edges of crystals (Fig. 4).  A simple physics-based model that idealizes the shapes of crystals and water-filled veins predicts the observed dependence on the square of the water content but overestimates the magnitude of the measured permeability values (Fig. 4). This overestimation likely reflects the irregular shapes of ice crystals and the associated tendency for some water-filled veins to be discontinuous and thus unable to conduct water.

These relationships are important because they will allow the water content of ice and the resultant speed at which glacier ice flows to be calculated more accurately in computer models than was possible previously.

Broader Impacts

The results of the ice-rheology experiments and permeability measurements, through their effect on modeling of fast-glacier flow, may benefit the larger community of scientists interested in assessing future sea-level rise. The permeability measurements will also allow the diffusion of isotopes through the water vein network to be accurately characterized, which is required to improve inferences of past climate change from isotopes measured in ice cored from ice sheets.  

This project also provided training and financial support for four ISU graduate students and two undergraduates, helping to launch their careers as geoscientists.

This project also created new infrastructure for research. It allowed two kinds experiments (Figs. 1 and 2) to be conducted that were previously not possible anywhere. The rotary ice-deformation device made possible shear experiments on large specimens of warm ice, allowing realistic grain sizes to be used and water content to be controlled and measured as an independent variable. The project also stimulated the construction of an ice permeameter, which is the only such instrument available for measuring the permeability of warm, freshwater ice. The diameter of the ice chamber of the permeameter allows ice cored from glaciers to be studied, paving the way for a new style of ice-core analysis relevant to fast glacier flow.
